====Philippines==== {{main article|Jollibee}} <!-- PLEASE INCLUDE CURRENT CITATION WHEN NUMBER OF LOCATIONS IS CHANGED --> The first ever Jollibee branch was in Cubao, [[Quezon City]] which opened in 1975 as a Magnolia Ice cream parlor. When Jollibee was incorporated in 1978, there were 7 branches in Metro Manila. The first franchised outlet of Jollibee opened in [[Santa Cruz, Manila]] in 1979.<ref name=milestonesasof2017>{{cite web|title=Milestones & History|url=http://www.jollibee.com.ph/about-us/milestones-history/|website=Jollibee|accessdate=19 October 2017}}</ref>
The fast food chain's first outlet outside [[Luzon]] was in [[Cagayan de Oro]] in [[Mindanao]].<ref name=milestonesasof2017/> The store opened in 1991 at the Limketkai Commercial Complex.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Valcobero|first1=Jennifer|title=Jollibee opens 18th branch in CDO|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cagayan-de-oro/business/2016/10/03/jollibee-opens-18th-branch-cdo-501303|accessdate=19 October 2017|work=Sun Star Cagayan de Oro|date=3 October 2016}}</ref>
The 100th branch in the Philippines opened in [[Davao City]] in 1991 while its 500th store opened in [[Basilan]] in 2004<ref name=JollibeeMilestonesHistory>{{cite web|url=http://www.jollibee.com.ph/about-us#milestones-history|title=About Us « Jollibee Foods Corporation|website=www.jollibee.com.ph}}</ref>
There were 954 Jollibee branded restaurant locations in the Philippines officially recorded to be operating during November 2016.<ref name=italycanada /> The 1,000th Jollibee store in the country at the [[Bonifacio Global City]] was opened in 2017. By the end of 2017, Jollibee has 1,062 stores in the Philppines<ref name="open1000"/>
====Elsewhere==== =====Middle East===== ======Kuwait====== The first location in [[Kuwait]] was opened 1994 but Jollibee left the Kuwaiti market in 1999.<ref name="zawya"/> Jollibee was reintroduced in the country in February 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ofwkuwait.net/jollibee-in-kuwait-opening/ |title=Jollibee in Kuwait opening on February 25 |date=20 February 2012 |website=OFW Kuwait |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
======Oman====== The first location in [[Oman]] was opened in Al Khuwayr in May 2017.<ref name="md-2017may03">{{cite news |url=http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Oman/New-fast-food-restaurant-Jollibee-gets-Filipino-community-excited-50he |title=New fast food restaurant Jollibee gets Filipino community excited |newspaper=[[Muscat Daily]] |date=May 3, 2017 |first=Faris |last=Al Hashmi}}</ref>
======Qatar====== Sunrise Trading & Foodstuff Co is the franchisee operating all Jollibee branches in the state of Qatar. The first branch in [[Qatar]] was opened in June 2010,<ref name="meed-2010jun19">{{cite news |url=https://www.meed.com/sectors/retail/philippines-jollibee-to-open-in-qatar/3054221.article |title=Philippines' Jollibee to open in Qatar |website=[[MEED]] |date=June 19, 2010 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |subscription=yes}}</ref>
======Saudi Arabia====== Nessma United Ltd. is the franchise company operating all Jollibee branches in Saudi Arabia. The first branch opened by the franchise company was at the Jeddah International Market in 2008. By December 2016 there are 12 Jollibee branches in the kingdom with presence in the cities of [[Al Khobar]] [[Jeddah]], [[Jubail]], [[Riyadh]], [[Taif]] and [[Yanbu]].<ref name="dfaksa">{{cite news|title=Jollibee opens 4th branch at the 2nd Industrial City in Riyadh|url=http://www.dfa.gov.ph/newsroom/phl-embassies-and-consulates-news/11383-jollibee-opens-4th-branch-at-the-2nd-industrial-city-in-riyadh|accessdate=27 December 2016|publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|date=22 December 2016}}</ref>
======United Arab Emirates====== [[File:Jollibee Abu Dhabi opening.jpg|thumb|Opening of the first Jollibee outlet in [[Abu Dhabi]] in December 2016.]] Jollibee opened its first store in the [[United Arab Emirates]] in April 1995 in [[Dubai]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Manila's Jollibee nets $3.44 million |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1995/05/02/Manilas-Jollibee-nets-344-million/1624799387200/ |accessdate=2 November 2015 |publisher=United Press International |date=2 May 1995 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> but later closed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/uae/general/filipinos-welcome-jollibee-s-plans-to-open-in-uae-1.1321143 |title=Filipinos welcome Jollibee's plans to open in UAE |date=18 April 2014 |first=Janice |last=Ponce de Leon |publisher=Gulf News |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> In February 2014, it was announced that Jollibee Food Corporation signed a joint venture agreement with Golden Crown Foods LLC to form a subsidiary company called Golden Plate Pte. Ltd. which was created to operate and own Jollibee stores in the United Arab Emirates.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Loyola |first1=James |title=Jollibee signs JV for UAE stores |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/jollibee-signs-jv-for-uae-stores/ |accessdate=27 December 2016 |work=Manila Bulletin |date=25 February 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806120038/http://www.mb.com.ph/jollibee-signs-jv-for-uae-stores/ |archivedate=6 August 2014 |df= }}</ref>In May 2015, Jollibee returned to the Emirati market by opening a store at the [[Dubai Mall]] in [[Dubai]].<ref name=uae2/><ref name=uae>{{cite news|title=Jollibee plans 25 stores across the UAE |url=http://filipinotimes.ae/news/2014/11/16/jollibee-plans-25-stores-across-the-uae/ |accessdate=25 March 2015 |publisher=The Filipino Times |date=16 November 2014 |author= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403101927/http://filipinotimes.ae/news/2014/11/16/jollibee-plans-25-stores-across-the-uae/ |archive-date=3 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=gn-2015may04>{{cite news |url=http://gulfnews.com/leisure/food/features/long-beeline-to-jollibee-dubai-mall-outlet-1.1504684 |title=Long beeline to Jollibee Dubai Mall outlet: Customers shocked by serpentine queues outside Jollibee Dubai store on Monday opening |newspaper=[[Gulf News]] |date=4 May 2015 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> The following year, a second location was opened in the [[Mall of the Emirates]] in February 2016,<ref name=tnad-2016mar10>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/retail/uae-perfect-location-to-set-filipino-favourite-jollibee-abuzz |title=UAE perfect location to set Filipino favourite Jollibee abuzz |newspaper=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date=10 March 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> quickly followed by a third location in [[BurJuman|BurJuman Centre]] in April 2016,<ref name=gn-2016apr14>{{cite news |url=http://gulfnews.com/business/sectors/retail/queues-are-back-as-jollibee-opens-biggest-dubai-restaurant-1.1711395 |title=Queues are back as Jollibee opens biggest Dubai restaurant: Latest store in Burjuman is Asian fast-food giant's first standalone outlet in UAE |newspaper=[[Gulf News]] |date=14 April 2016 |first=Cleofe |last=Maceda}}</ref> and a fourth store in Al Ghurair Center opened in August 2016.<ref name=tft-2016aug04>{{cite news |url=http://filipinotimes.ae/news/2016/08/04/jollibee-opens-4th-branch-in-al-ghurair-centre/ |title=Jollibee Opens 4th Branch in Al Ghurair Centre |website=The Filipino Times |date=4 August 2016 |first=Anne Lora |last=Santos}}</ref>
In December 28, 2016, the first Jollibee outlet in Abu Dhabi opened at the Mushrif Mall.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lau|first1=Evelyn|title=Fast food chain Jollibee to open first Abu Dhabi branch in Mushrif Mall|url=http://www.thenational.ae/blogs/bites/fast-food-chain-jollibee-to-open-first-abu-dhabi-branch-in-mushrif-mall|accessdate=11 January 2017|work=The National|date=27 December 2016}}</ref> =====East Asia===== ======Hong Kong====== Jollibee opened its first branch in Hong Kong in 1996<ref name="morejoyhk">{{cite news|title=Jollibee serves more joy in Hong Kong with the opening of two new stores|url=http://business.inquirer.net/246390/jollibee-serves-joy-hong-kong-opening-two-new-stores|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|agency=INQUIRER.net BrandRoom|date=23 February 2018}}</ref> in the [[Central, Hong Kong|Central District]]<ref name="ejinsight">{{cite news|title=Jollibee aims to add 11 outlets in HK in five years|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20170424-jollibee-aims-to-add-11-outlets-in-hk-in-five-years/|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=Ejinsight|publisher=Hong Kong Economic Journal Company Ltd.|date=24 April 2017}}</ref> when its was still [[British Hong Kong|under British administration]]. The number of outlets in the city which shortly became a Chinese territory grew to five but the fast food brand saw closure of outlets.<ref name="ejinsight"/> In 2016, Jollibee started reopening outlets.<ref name="morejoyhk"/><ref name="ejinsight"/> By December 2017 there are 8 Jollibee outlets in Hong Kong.<ref name="morejoyhk"/> ======Macau====== The first Jollibee outlet in [[Macau]] opened on June 28, 2018 at Circle Square<ref name="macau">{{cite news |title=Jollibee food opens first Macau branch |url=https://business.mb.com.ph/2018/06/28/jollibee-food-opens-first-macau-branch/ |accessdate=4 July 2018 |work=Manila Bulletin |date=28 June 2018}}</ref> at Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.macaupostdaily.com/article4771.html|title=Opening of Macau’s 1st Jollibee draws huge Philippine crowd|website=www.macaupostdaily.com}}</ref>
=====Southeast Asia===== ======Singapore====== The first location in [[Singapore]] was opened in March 2013. The company that operates the franchise in this country is jointly owned by Beeworks Inc. and a wholly owned Jollibee subsidiary called Golden Plate Pte. Ltd.<ref name=abs-cbn-2013mar05>{{cite news |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/business/03/05/13/jollibee-opens-1st-singapore-store-march-12 |title=Jollibee opens 1st Singapore store on March 12 |website=[[ABS-CBN]] |date=5 March 2013 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> In April 2016, Jollibee had opened its third and fourth location on this island [[city-state]].<ref name="cs-2016apr04">{{cite news |url=http://singapore.coconuts.co/2016/04/04/jollibee-opens-2-new-stores-changi-and-novena-launches-3-new-items-specially-local-palate |title=Jollibee opens 2 new stores in Changi and Novena; launches 3 new items specially for local palate |website=Coconuts Singapore |date=April 4, 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
======Vietnam====== The first Jollibee branch in [[Vietnam]] was opened in October 1996 at the {{sic|Sup|erbowl Mall}} in [[Ho Chi Minh City]].<ref name="sggp-2009mar09" /> By 2010, Jollibee had 10 locations in Vietnam, all located in Ho Chi Minh City except for a lone branch located in [[Bien Hoa City]].<ref name="sggp-2009mar09">{{cite news |url=http://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Business/2009/3/69068/ |title=Jollibee to strengthen business in Vietnam |newspaper=[[Sai Gon Giai Phong]] |date=March 9, 2009 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> By the end of 2011, the 30th branch was opened in the Long Binh District of Hanoi.<ref name="vir-2011dec28">{{cite news |url=http://www.vir.com.vn/jollibee-opens-30th-store-in-vietnam.html |title=Jollibee opens 30th store in Vietnam |website=Vietnam Investment Review |date=December 28, 2011 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
Jollibee had no less than 20 stores in Vietnam as of 2012, with branches in the cities of [[Ho Chi Minh City]], [[Hanoi]], [[Da Nang]], [[Nha Trang]], in the provinces of [[Vinh Phuc]], [[Đồng Nai Province|Dong Nai]] and in the Mekong Delta Region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hrvietnam.com/en/nha-tuyen-dung/jollibee-vietnam.35A52387.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121126053335/http://hrvietnam.com/en/nha-tuyen-dung/jollibee-vietnam.35A52387.html|archive-date=November 26, 2012 |title=Jollibee Vietnam|accessdate=August 6, 2012}}</ref>
By the beginning of 2018, Jollibee opened 100 stores in Vietnam, and it's 100th branch opened in [[Can Tho]].
===Europe=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:78%; " width:100%; background:yellow; |- ! style="width:2%;" |No. ! style="width:13%;" |Country / Territory ! style="width:15%;" |Date of first store ! style="width:13%;" |First outlet location ! style="width:14%;" |Current number of outlets {{nowrap|{{small|(Date of source)}}}} ! style="width:20%;" |Notes ! style="width:5%;" |References |- | align=center|1 |{{flag|Italy}} |March 2018 |[[Milan]], [[Lombardy]] |1 (March 2018) | |<ref name=ciaoitaly>{{cite news|last1=Mulingtapang|first1=Mye|title=Ciao Italy: Jollibee opens first store in Europe|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/business/03/19/18/ciao-italy-jollibee-opens-first-store-in-europe|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=ABS-CBN|agency=ABS-CBN Europe News Bureau|date=19 March 2018}}</ref> |- | align=center|2 |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |October 2018 |[[London]], [[England]] |1 (October 2018) | |<ref name="dt">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/10/17/chicken-beef-not-have-jollibee-launches-britain/|title=Chicken or beef... why not have both? Jollibee launches in Britain|first=Oliver|last=Gill|date=17 October 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> |} In 2013, Jollibee president and CEO Tony Tan Caktiong stated that Jollibee had plans to open a branch in Europe due to popular demand, but that such plans were not then prioritized.<ref name="tonycaktiong"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/business/07/22/13/jollibee-eyes-foray-european-market|title=Jollibee plans to enter European market |accessdate=May 1, 2014 |publisher=ABS-CBN News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/business/75056/jollibee-aims-to-become-asias-top-fast-food-chain-in-2015|title=Jollibee aims to become Asia's top fast-food chain in 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2014|publisher=InterAksyon|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140430052150/http://www.interaksyon.com/business/75056/jollibee-aims-to-become-asias-top-fast-food-chain-in-2015|archivedate=April 30, 2014|df=}}</ref> However, it was later reported in March 2015 that Jollibee planned to expand to Europe through an unspecified country in 2017-2018.<ref name=JapanEU>{{cite news|last1=Mercurio|first1=Richmond|title=Jollibee goes to Canada this year; Europe, Japan next|url=http://rp1.abs-cbnnews.com/business/03/24/15/jollibee-goes-canada-year-europe-japan-next|accessdate=25 March 2015|publisher=ABS-CBN|date=25 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402115813/http://rp1.abs-cbnnews.com/business/03/24/15/jollibee-goes-canada-year-europe-japan-next|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}}</ref>
Caktiong also announced in a forum on October 29, 2015 Jollibee's plan to open its first branches in Italy and the United Kingdom.<ref name=ukitaly>{{cite news|last1=Montealegre|first1=Krista|title=Jollibee aims to expand in UK, Italy next year|url=http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Corporate&title=jollibee-aims-to-expand-in-uk-italy-next-year&id=117911|accessdate=2 November 2015|publisher=BusinessWorld|date=1 November 2015}}</ref> The first European outlets were opened in Italy and the United Kingdom in 2018.
====Italy==== The first Jollibee outlet in Italy and in whole of Europe opened at the Piazza Diaz 7<ref name=firsteurope>{{cite news|title=Jollibee opens first store in Europe|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/lifestyle/food/262064/jollibee-opens-first-store-in-europe.html|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=The Standard|date=1 April 2018}}</ref> in [[Milan]], [[Italy]] on March 18, 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mulingtapang|first1=Mye|title=This Pinoy Fast Food Chain Launching In Milan Somehow Shakes The Italians|url=https://lifestyle.abs-cbn.com/articles/6388/in-focus-jollibee-and-its-sweet-style-spaghetti-launching-in-milan-somehow-shakes-the-italians/|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=ABS-CBN|date=31 March 2018}}</ref> [[Jollibee Foods Corporation]]'s entrance in the European market was a result of a joint venture with Singapore Blackbird Holdings.<ref name=firsteurope/> JFC announced the joint venture in April 2017.<ref name="goeseurope">{{cite news|last1=Dumlao-Abadilla|first1=Doris|title=Jollibee goes to Europe, eyes first store in Italy|url=http://business.inquirer.net/227326/jollibee-goes-europe-eyes-first-store-italy|accessdate=19 October 2017|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=4 April 2017}}</ref> Plans to open a Jollibee branch in Italy already existed as early as August 2015 when Jollibee officials met with Milan's Chamber of Commerce to discuss possibilities on opening a branch in the northern Italian city.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jollibee to open in Milan|url=https://dfa.gov.ph/news-from-our-foreign-service-posts/7080-jollibee-to-open-in-milan|accessdate=19 October 2017|publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs|date=15 August 2015}}</ref>
====United Kingdom==== Jollibee opened its first UK outlet in [[Earl's Court]], London on 18 October 2018.<ref name="dt"/> Out of the planned 50 outlets to be opened in Europe by 2023, half of which are planned to be opened in the United Kingdom.<ref name=readies1ststoreuk>{{cite web|url=https://www.philstar.com/business/2018/10/18/1860885/jollibee-readies-opening-1st-store-uk|title=Jollibee readies opening of 1st store in UK (First Paragraph)|first=Josh|last=Obaob|date=23 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.philstar.com}}</ref>
===North America=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:78%; " width:100%; background:yellow; |- ! style="width:2%;" |No. ! style="width:13%;" |Country / Territory ! style="width:15%;" |Date of first store ! style="width:13%;" |First outlet location ! style="width:14%;" |Current number of outlets {{nowrap|{{small|(Date of source)}}}} ! style="width:20%;" |Notes ! style="width:5%;" |References |- | align=center|1 |{{flag|United States}} |June 1998 |[[Daly City]], [[California]] |39 (23 November 2018) | | |- | align=center|2 |{{flag|Canada}} |December 15, 2016 |[[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]] |5 (1 November, 2018) | | |}
====United States==== In the United States, Jollibee has locations in [[California]], [[Hawaii]], [[Nevada]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Texas]], [[Illinois]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jollibeeusa.com/storelocator.html |title=Store Locator |publisher=Jollibee USA |date=<!--undated--> |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
[[File:Jollibee National City.jpg|thumb|Jollibee location in [[National City, California]]]] The first location in the United States was opened in [[Daly City, California]] in June 1998.<ref name=sjmn-1998jun10>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB721DC95CB1A3D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Fast-food Chain From Asia Lands In Daly City |newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |date=June 10, 1998 |page=2F |first=Carolyn |last=Jung |subscription=yes |quote=Jollibee International, Asia's fastest-growing food service organization, is opening its first U.S. restaurant on Saturday in Daly City.}}</ref> After a two-year wait, a second Northern California location was opened in [[Union City, California|Union City]] in April 2000.<ref name=sjmn-2000apr02>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB714B9E8800FB9&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Opening Of Jollibee's: Taste Of The Philippines |newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |date=April 2, 2000 |page=1B |first=Sandra |last=Gonzales |subscription=yes |quote=With its debut in Union City last week, Jollibee -- Asia's fastest-growing food chain -- continues to roll along on its expansion plans to open 30 more California outlets, including one in San Jose and in Vallejo, by the end of next year. Union City's store is only Jollibee's second U.S. restaurant. The company opened its first in Daly City in 1998.}}.</ref> Two month later, the first location in Southern California, the third in the United States, was opened in [[Carson, California|Carson]] in June 2000.<ref name=tdb-2000jun21>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BRZB&p_theme=brzb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=1124BB2FAED68E08&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Business Dealings |newspaper=[[Torrance Daily Breeze]] |date=June 21, 2000 |page=D8 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |subscription=yes |quote=Jollibee, a Philippine fast food chain, recently opened its first store in Southern California at the corner of Carson and Main streets in Carson. The chain plans to open two more stores this summer in Long Beach and Cerritos.}}</ref> In the following month, the second location in Southern California, the fourth in the United States, was opened in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] in July 2000.<ref name=lbpt-2000jul13>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LBPB&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAE8B3F74AB7BE3&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Jollibee Brings Taste Of Philippines to L.B. |newspaper=[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]] |date=July 13, 2000 |page=A23 |first=John W. |last=Cox |subscription=yes |quote=A new Jollibee restaurant opened Wednesday at the Wrigley Marketplace shopping center, continuing the Filipino chain's expansion in the U.S. The 2,700-square-foot store, at 281 E. Willow St. in Long Beach, lands in a fast-food hotbed, built nearly adjacent to a McDonald's, a Carl's Jr. and a Burger King... After opening a Jollibee in Carson last month, the company's strategy for opening in Long Beach is not to focus on just Asians, but to appeal to the broadest possible customer base... Jollibee has the usual fare that most fast-food restaurants have: hamburgers, french fries, and children's meals. But Jollibee burgers are sweeter than other chains, primarily because its Asian-Pacific customer base prefers the flavor.}}</ref> The first [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] area restaurant, the fifth in the United States, was opened at [[National City, California|National City]] in July 2001.<ref name=sdut-2001jul05>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SDUB&p_theme=sdub&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=116D35B8786A083D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Where's the 'Bee? Beefing up the Burger Wars, Jollibee Comes to Town with Fast Food, Filipino Style |newspaper=[[San Diego Union Tribune]] |date=July 5, 2001 |pages=D-1 |first=Gil |last=Griffin |subscription=yes |quote=Jollibee is coming. On Monday, the Philippines' most popular fast-food chain -- famous for its cutesy, cartoonish bee mascot and sweetly spiced hamburgers and spaghetti -- is scheduled to make its San Diego County debut. And if this Jollibee launch at 1401 E. Plaza Blvd. is anything like previous ones in Daly City, Union City, Carson and Long Beach, expect swarms of hungry, happy -- and homesick -- customers to make such a beeline that it may take hours to get to the counter and the drive-thru window.}}</ref> The first location in [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] was opened in [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]] in September 2011.<ref name="ocr-2011sep30">{{cite news |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/jollibee-592532-strong-food.html |title=Filipino fast-food giant, Jollibee, debuts Saturday |newspaper=[[Orange County Register]] |date=September 30, 2011 |first=Nancy |last=Luna}}</ref> The first location in [[San Bernardino County, California|San Bernardino County]] was opened in [[Rancho Cucamonga, California|Rancho Cucamonga]] in November 2013.<ref name="is-2013nov26">{{cite news |url=http://www.insidesocal.com/dine909/2013/11/26/seafood-city-three-new-filipino-eateries-open-in-rancho-cucamonga/ |title=Seafood City, three new Filipino eateries open in Rancho Cucamonga |website=Inside Socal |date=November 26, 2013 |first=John |last=Plessel}}</ref>
Not all locations in California were successful and several had closed after operating briefly.<ref name=vth-2006jan28>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesheraldonline.com/article/ZZ/20060128/NEWS/601289950 |title=Jollibee quietly closes doors |newspaper=[[Vallejo Times Herald]] |date=January 28, 2006 |first=Rachel |last=Raskin-Zrihen |quote=Just six years after entering the Vallejo market with great fanfare, the Park Place Shopping Center Jollibee, the Philippines' answer to McDonald's, quietly went out of business... There are nine Jollibee locations in the United States and another will open next month in Los Angeles, De le Cruz said. Besides Vallejo's, stores have closed in San Francisco and Long Beach and neither has reopened, she said... But the popularity of Jollibee's hamburgers, spaghetti, chicken pieces and peach mango pie seems to have fallen flat, at least in north Vallejo... He said he believes Vallejo's Jollibee closed because it was too far from the city's major Filipino population center.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livesoma.com/2010/12/03/two-less-eateries-in-south-of-market/ |title=Two Less Eateries in South of Market... |date=December 3, 2010 |website=Live Soma |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319223940/http://www.livesoma.com/2010/12/03/two-less-eateries-in-south-of-market/ |archive-date=2011-03-19 |deadurl=yes |quote=As of November 30th, there are two less eateries near the Metreon. I'm sorry to report that both Jollibee (200 Fourth St) and the Red Ribbon Bakeshop (also at 200 Fourth St) have closed their doors for good at their Fourth Street locations.}}</ref>
The first location in the state of Nevada, and the first U.S. location outside of California and the 12th in the United States, was opened in the [[Las Vegas]] in May 2007.<ref name=lvw-2007jun27>{{cite news |url=http://lasvegasweekly.com/news/archive/2007/jun/27/encyclopedia-vegas-brief-entries-on-eating-art3/ |title=Joy to be had at multi-hued Jollibee |newspaper=[[Las Vegas Weekly]] |date=June 27, 2007 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref><ref name=mbj-2007may28>{{cite news |url=https://mbjguam.com/2007/05/28/jollibee-to-feed-u-s-and-guam-outlets-2/ |title=Jollibee to feed U.S. and Guam outlets |website= Marianas Business Journal |date=May 28, 2007 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |quote=Jollibee USA plans to open five new stores in 2007 — Jollibee Las Vegas [opened May 2] Jollibee San Bruno and Vallejo California will open around September or October and Jollibee Sacramento and in the Panorama Mall [in Panorama City Calif.] by December. Jollibee Las Vegas is the 12th store of the fast-food outlet in U.S. mainland.}}</ref>
Moving east, the company opened its first location in the state of New York in [[Queens]] in [[New York City]] in February 2009.<ref name=se-2009feb>{{cite news |url=http://newyork.seriouseats.com/2009/02/jollibee-filipino-fast-food-woodside-queens-nyc.html |title=Woodside's Jollibee Jam-Packed with Nostalgic Filipinos |website=[[Serious Eats]] |date=February 2009 |first=Joe |last=DiStefano}}</ref><ref name=nyt-2009mar10>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/11/dining/reviews/11brief-002.html |title=Jollibee Brings a Filipino Addiction to Queens |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=March 10, 2009 |first=Matt |last=Gross}}</ref> This was the first location east of the [[Rockies]]. In October 2018, the company opened its second location in New York State on the island of [[Manhattan]] in NYC.<ref name="en-2018oct29">{{cite news |url=https://ny.eater.com/2018/10/29/18038588/jollibee-manhattan-opening-long-lines-nyc |title=Hardcore Fans Camped Out for Filipino Icon Jollibee's Manhattan Opening: The first two in line got there 20 hours early for a taste of the Filipino fast food |website=[[Eater NY]] |date=October 29, 2018 |first=Stefanie |last=Tuder}}</ref>
The first location in the state of Washington was opened in [[Tukwila, Washington|Tukwila]] in September 2010.<ref name=tr-2010nov08>{{cite news |url=http://www.tukwilareporter.com/news/jollibee-restaurant-brings-taste-of-philippines-to-tukwila/ |title=Jollibee Restaurant brings taste of Philippines to Tukwila |newspaper=[[Tukwila reporter|Tukwila Reporter]] |date=November 8, 2010 |first=Steve |last=Hunter |quote=Jollibee opened in September on the northeast side of the mall (Westfield Southcenter Mall in Tukwila)}}</ref>
The first location in the state of Hawaii, and the 27th in the United States, was opened in [[Waipahu, Hawaii|Waipahu]] in December 2010.<ref name=hsa-2010dec14>{{cite news |url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2010/12/14/business/jollibee-will-be-abuzz-with-its-opening-today/ |title=Jollibee will be abuzz with its opening today |newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]] |date=December 14, 2010 |first=Erika |last=Engle |quote=Hawaii's first Jollibee is No. 27 for the company in the U.S.}}</ref> A second Hawaiian location was opened in the [[Ala Moana Center]] the following year in November 2011.<ref name="pbn-2011oct24">{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/morning_call/2011/10/jollibee-red-ribbon-bakeshop-opening.html |title=Jollibee, Red Ribbon BakeShop opening new Oahu stores |work=[[Pacific Business News]] |date=October 24, 2011 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> Three years later, a third Hawaiian location was opened in [[Kalihi]] in April 2014.<ref name="pbn-2014jan16">{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2014/01/16/jollibee-to-open-third-hawaii.html |title=Jollibee to open third Hawaii restaurant on Oahu |work=[[Pacific Business News]] |date=January 16, 2014 |first=Duane |last=Shimogawa}}</ref>
The first location in the state of New Jersey, and the second location on the East Coast, was opened in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]] in June 2012.<ref name=wsj-2012jun11>{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/djreprints/doc/1019607302.html |title=Sweet Spaghetti, And a Bit of Pride |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=June 11, 2012 |page=A15 |last=Haddon |first=Heather |subscription=yes |quote=Jersey City's Filipinos turned out in droves on Sunday for the opening of the East Coast's second Jollibee}} [http://search.proquest.com/docview/1019607302/ Alternate Link] via [[ProQuest]].</ref><ref name=nj.com-2012jun10>{{cite news |url=http://www.nj.com/hudson/index.ssf/2012/06/throngs_flock_to_jollibee_fili.html |title=Throngs flock to Jollibee, Filipino fast-food eatery now open in Jersey City |website=[[NJ.com]] |date=June 10, 2012 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref><ref name=wnyc-2012aug09>{{cite news |url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/228734-jollibee-restaurant-follows-filipino-community-new-jersey/ |title=Jollibee Restaurant Follows Filipino Community to New Jersey |website=[[WNYC]] |date=August 9, 2012 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> The following year, the first location in the state of Virginia, and the third location on the East Coast, was opened in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]] in April 2013.<ref name=virginian-pilot-2013apr07>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=14589AD3368DBE78&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Filipino-food fans, the wait is over ... |newspaper=[[Virginian-Pilot]] |date=April 7, 2013 |page=B1 |first=Margaret |last=Matray |subscription=yes |quote=The restaurant opens its doors at 7 a.m. today at Brenneman Farm Marketplace at South Plaza Trail and Princess Anne Road. It will be the first Jollibee to open in the mid-Atlantic region and the third on the East Coast. Based in the Philippines, the chain has about two dozen restaurants open in the United States, including one in Queens, N.Y., and another in Jersey City, N.J.}}</ref>
[[File:JollibeeHoustonTX.jpg|thumb|Jollibee location in [[Houston]], [[Texas]]]] The first location in the state of Texas, and the 26th in the United States, was opened in [[Houston]] in September 2013.<ref name=hc-2013sep25>{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/entertainment/restaurants-bars/reviews/article/At-Jollibee-it-s-fast-food-with-Filipino-twist-4843150.php |title=At Jollibee, it's fast food with Filipino twist |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=September 25, 2013 |first=Alison |last=Cook |quote=grand opening last Thursday... 26 locations in the United States}}</ref>
The first location in the state of Illinois, and the 34th in the United States, was opened in [[Skokie, Illinois|Skokie]] in July 2016.<ref name=ec-2016jul29>{{cite news |url=http://chicago.eater.com/2016/7/29/12323790/jollibee-opening-photos-chicago-skokie-filipino-restaurant |title=Jollibee's Long-Awaited Unveiling Brings the Philippines to Chicagoland: Folks are waiting hours on opening day |website=Eater Chicago |date=July 29, 2016 |first=Ashok |last=Selvam |quote=The restaurant officially swung open its doors at 7 a.m. today, introducing suburban Skokie to fried chicken, burgers and Filipino spaghetti.}}</ref>
In September 2016, Jollibee announced the construction of their first location in the state of Florida and expects that the location in [[Jacksonville]] to be opened toward the end of the year. At the time of the announcement, Jollibee had approximately 35 locations within the United States.<ref name=jdr-2016sep20>{{cite news |url=https://www.jaxdailyrecord.com/showstory.php?Story_id=547487 |title=Jollibee expects to open first Jacksonville store in mid-December |newspaper=[[Jacksonville Daily Record]] |date=September 20, 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |quote=With construction underway, Jollibee is expected to open its first Jacksonville location in mid-December at southwest Atlantic and Kernan boulevards in Southside... Its more than 30 U.S. locations comprise more than 20 in California along with stores in Hawaii, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Washington and Virginia.}}</ref> After announcing, missing, and changing the expected opening date for this company-owned location several times, Jollibee announced in late December that they expect to open this location "soon".<ref name="pdi-2016dec23">{{cite news |url=http://usa.inquirer.net/644/opening-soon-jollibee-tells-eager-fil-ams-jacksonville |title=Opening 'soon,' Jollibee tells eager Fil-Ams in Jacksonville |website=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=December 23, 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> The Jollibee restaurant in Jacksonville eventually opened its doors on March 18, 2017, one day after Saint Patrick's Day.<ref name="pdi-2017mar18">{{cite news |url=https://www.jaxdailyrecord.com/showstory.php?Story_id=549569 |title=Jollibee welcomes 3,000 customers on first day in Jacksonville |website=[[Jacksonville Daily Record]] |date=March 18, 2017 |first=Karen Brune |last=Mathis}}</ref>
On October 27, 2018, Jollibee opened its second New York branch in Manhattan.
In 2023, Jollibee expected to have 150 stores across the United States. <ref>https://news.abs-cbn.com/business/11/19/18/jollibee-to-build-more-stores-in-us-canada</ref>
==== Canada ==== In 2015, Jollibee first indicated it would expand to Canada with plans to open the first Canadian branch in [[Toronto]].<ref name=thestandardnov1.2015/>
The first Canadian Jollibee location opened in December 2016 in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]].<ref name=ckjs-2016dec01>{{cite news |url=http://ckjs.com/filipino-fast-food-chain-jollibee-is-officially-coming-to-canada/ |title=It is Official: First Jollibee in Winnipeg Opens December 15 |newspaper=[[CKJS]] |date=2016-12-01 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref><ref name="cn-2016dec15">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/jollibee-filipino-restaurant-open-winnipeg-1.3897658 |title=Jollibee's 1st Canadian location opens in Winnipeg as hundreds wait in line: American-style fast food restaurant with Filipino-influenced dishes called the McDonald's of the Philippines |website=[[CBC News]] |date=December 15, 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> The city was chosen as the first Jollibee location by JFC due to it being the Canadian city with the highest density of Filipinos.<ref name="bn-2016dec15">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38333694 |title=Filipino fast food chain Jollibee's opens in Winnipeg |website=[[BBC News]] |date=15 December 2016 |first1=Jessica |last1=Murphy |first2=Robin |last2=Levinson-King |last-author-amp=yes}}</ref> For the opening ceremony, the fast food's eponymous mascot wore a [[tuque]] and [[scarf]],<ref name="bn-2016dec15" /> which are not worn in the Philippines, over its usual costume. The location became the 35th in North America, with the other 34 locations in the United States.<ref name="gn-2016dec14">{{cite news |url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3127107/jollibee-opens-first-canadian-store-in-winnipeg/ |title=Jollibee arrives in Winnipeg, dozens brave the cold for grand opening |website=[[Global News]] |date=December 14, 2016 |first=Katie |last=Dangerfield}}</ref> On November 27, 2017, Jollibee opened a second location in Winnipeg at the [[Northgate Mall (Winnipeg)|Northgate Mall]].<ref name="cbcmanitoba-2017nov28">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/second-jolibee-opens-winnipeg-1.4422662. |title=2nd Jolibee opening draws overnight lineups and morning crowds |website=CBC Manitoba |date=November 28, 2017 |first=Elisha |last=Dacey}}</ref>
In August 2017, Jollibee announced plans to open two new Canadian locations in the Toronto area, with one in [[Mississauga]] and the other in [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]], before the end of fall 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.narcity.com/ca/on/toronto/news/jollibee-to-finally-open-in-mississauga-this-fall-2017 |title=Jollibee To Finally Open In Mississauga This Fall 2017: After months of delays. |website=Narcity |date=August 25, 2017 |first=Eul |last=Basa}}</ref> Two months later, Jollibee revised their plans and said that the earliest either store would open is early spring 2018.<ref name="narcity-2017oct02">{{cite news |url=https://www.narcity.com/ca/on/toronto/news/jollibee-grand-opening-date-in-mississauga-pushed-to-2018 |title=Jollibee Grand Opening Date In Mississauga Pushed To 2018: Just a little bit longer! |website=Narcity |date=October 2, 2017 |first=Eul |last=Basa}}</ref> The Scarborough location opened on April 1, 2018 <ref>{{cite news|last1=Kerr|first1=Jaren|title=Jollibee, ‘McDonald’s of the Philippines,’ opening attracts thousands in Scarborough|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2018/04/01/jollibee-mcdonalds-of-the-philippines-opening-attracts-thousands-in-scarborough.html|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=1 April 2018}}</ref> and the Mississauga location shortly afterward on July 20, 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vertolli|first1=Rizieiro|title=Jollibee opens newest outlet in Mississauga's Seafood City|url=https://www.mississauga.com/news-story/8753215-jollibee-opens-newest-outlet-in-mississauga-s-seafood-city/|accessdate=26 September 2018|work=[[Mississauga.com]]|date = 20 July 2018}}</ref>
In June 2018, Jollibee announced that they plan to open 100 locations across Canada by 2023.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/filipino-fast-food-chain-jollibee-to-open-100-canadian-stores-in-next-five-years-1.3970041| title=Filipino fast food chain Jollibee to open 100 Canadian stores in next five years| date=12 June 2018| website=[[CTV News]]}}</ref>
==Former branches== [[File:Jolibee former branches.svg|thumb|300px|Countries and territories formerly with Jollibee outlets in peach.]] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:78%; " width:100%; background:yellow; |- ! style="width:20%;" |Country / Territory ! style="width:15%;" |Date of first store ! style="width:20%;" |First outlet location ! style="width:15%;" |Date of closure of last store ! style="width:5%;" |References |- |{{flag|China PR}} |1998 |[[Xiamen]], [[Fujian]] |2001 | |- |{{flag|Guam}} |1996 |N/A |before 2009 | |- |{{flag|Indonesia}} |1991 |[[Jakarta]] |c. 1997/2000 |<ref name="wsj-1995oct03"/> |- |{{flag|Malaysia}} |N/A |N/A |c. 1997 |<ref name=thestandardnov1.2015>{{cite news|last1=Austria|first1=Jenniffer|title=Jollibee expanding to UK, Italy, Oman|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/business/190845/jollibee-expanding-to-uk-italy-oman.html|accessdate=2 November 2015|publisher=The Standard|date=1 November 2015}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Northern Mariana Islands}} |1999 |[[Garapan]], [[Saipan]] |2009 | |- |{{flag|Papua New Guinea}} |1997 |[[Port Moresby]] |N/A | |- |{{flag|Taiwan}} |1986 |N/A |N/A | |- |} ===Asia=== Jollibee had former branches in Taiwan, China and the United Arab Emirates. Jollibee launched its first branch in Taiwan in 1986, also its first branch outside the Philippines.<ref>{{cite web|title=Milestones & History|url=http://www.jollibee.com.ph/about-us/milestones-history/|publisher=Jollibee Foods Corporation|accessdate=7 January 2015|archive-date=19 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319023031/http://www.jollibee.com.ph/about-us/milestones-history/}}</ref> Jollibee had at least two branches in Taiwan.<ref name="wt-1990may31"/> Jollibee launched its first mainland China branch in [[Xiamen]] in 1998 but later closed in 2001. Jollibee focused on acquiring already popular restaurant chains in China.<ref name="tonycaktiong">{{cite news|title=Billionaire Tony Tan Caktiong Takes Jollibee Foods Global|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesasia/2013/01/30/billionaire-tony-tan-caktiong-takes-jollibee-foods-global/|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=Forbes Asia|date=11 February 2013}}</ref> Jollibee launched its first branch in Dubai in 1995 but it was later closed.<ref name="uae2"/> Jollibee previously had branches in Malaysia and Indonesia but were later closed down due to the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]].<ref name="expand"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Morales|first1=Neil Jerome|title=Jollibee expanding to Malaysia, Indonesia|url=http://www.philstar.com/business/2014/08/07/1354576/jollibee-expanding-malaysia-indonesia|accessdate=31 March 2015|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=7 August 2014}}</ref> Jollibee entered the Indonesian market in 1991 and by 1995 it had two stores in [[Jakarta]].<ref name="wsj-1995oct03"/>
===Oceania=== Jollibee had two branches on the island of [[Saipan]] in the [[Northern Mariana Islands]], a U.S. territory. The first location was opened in the village of [[Garapan]] in late 1999.<ref name=st-1999dec10>{{cite news |url=http://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/953a587b-1dfb-11e4-aedf-250bc8c9958e/ |title=Jollibee…let’s do lunch, babe |newspaper=[[Saipan Tribune]] |date=December 10, 1999 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> A second location was opened in the village of [[Chalan Kanoa]] in January 2000.<ref>{{cite news |title=Second Jollibee store opens in January |url=http://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/965320f9-1dfb-11e4-aedf-250bc8c9958e/ |accessdate=2 November 2015 |newspaper=[[Saipan Tribune]] |date=31 October 2000 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> The Chalan Kanoa branch was closed in 2004<ref name=st-2004jul08>{{cite news |url=http://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/9fe147d7-1dfb-11e4-aedf-250bc8c9958e/ |title=Jollibee outlet shuts down |newspaper=[[Saipan Tribune]] |date=July 8, 2004 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> and the main Garapan branch closed in February 2009 due to declining sales.<ref name="NMIclose">{{cite news |title=Jollibee to close in Feb. |url=http://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/b3271073-1dfb-11e4-aedf-250bc8c9958e/ |accessdate=2 November 2015 |newspaper=[[Saipan Tribune]] |date=26 November 2009 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
On the island of [[Guam]], another U.S. territory, Jollibee had opened a location there in 1996<ref name=upi-1996jan09>{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1996/01/09/Manila-fastfood-earns-big-in-Guam/4851821163600/ |title=Manila fastfood earns big in Guam |newspaper=[[United Press International]] |date=January 9, 1996 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> but later closed the branch sometime before 2009.<ref name="NMIclose"/> A second location was reported to have opened in the [[Agana Shopping Center]] in February 2000.<ref name="pdn-2000feb18">{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/guampdn/doc/910417695.html |title=Jollibee opens in Hagatna |newspaper=[[Pacific Daily News]] |date=February 18, 2000 |page=A61 |last=Jojola |first=Lloyd |subscription=yes}} [http://search.proquest.com/docview/910417695/ Alternate Link] via [[ProQuest]].</ref> There are no records on when the second location had closed, but no Jollibee locations are known to exist on the island of Guam by 2009.
Jollibee also had a branch in [[Papua New Guinea]] which opened in 1997 in [[Port Moresby]]. The branch closed following the publication of a newspaper print advertisement that falsely implied that the local branch was trying to purchase dogs and cats as a source of food. Jollibee was unable to track down those responsible for the ad but had suspected several competitors.<ref>{{cite book |first1=John L. |last1=Thompson |first2=Frank |last2=Martin |last-author-amp=yes |title=Strategic management : awareness and change |date=2005 |publisher=Thomson Learning |location=London [u.a.] |isbn=1844800830 |page=769 |edition=5th |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=INy2SHeqMhwC&lpg=PA769&ots=v6vus8bTYQ&dq=jollibee%20in%20papua%20new%20guinea%20-prezi&pg=PA769#v=onepage&q=jollibee%20in%20papua%20new%20guinea%20-prezi&f=false |via=[[Google Books]]}}</ref>
==Planned locations== ===Europe=== Jollibee has previously targeted to open a branch in [[Romania]] in 1995.<ref name="wsj-1995oct03b">{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/djreprints/doc/398474745.html |title=Philippines' Largest Fast-Food Chain Looks to Extend Its Overseas Reach |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=October 3, 1995 |edition=Eastern |first=Rexie |last=Reyes |subscription=yes |quote=}} [http://search.proquest.com/docview/398474745/ Alternate Link] via [[ProQuest]].</ref><ref name="upi-1995aug15">{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1995/08/15/Manilas-Jollibee-to-expand-abroad/3721808459200/ |title=Manila's Jollibee to expand abroad |newspaper=[[United Press International]] |date=August 15, 1995 |first=Jason |last=Gutierrez |quote=The Philippines' largest fast food chain said Tuesday it plans to set up 10 outlets in Guam, Hong Kong, Bahrain, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Malaysia and Romania.}}</ref> Plans to open a branch in Spain has been announced announced in October 2017.<ref name="chinaus">{{cite news|last1=Sayson|first1=Ian|last2=Wong|first2=Sterling|title=Jollibee Foods eyeing more acquisitions in US and China|url=https://business.mb.com.ph/2017/10/13/jollibee-foods-eyeing-more-acquisitions-in-us-and-china/|accessdate=19 October 2017|work=Manila Bulletin|agency=Bloomberg|date=13 October 2017}}</ref>
===Asia Pacific=== ====Australia and Japan==== In an October 2015 forum, Jollibee president and CEO Tony Tan Caktiong announced that Jollibee planned to open their first branches in [[Australia]] and [[Japan]] by 2017.<ref name=thestandardnov1.2015/> In a signing ceremony on October 26, 2016, Caktiong said that Jollibee may open stores in Japan in 2018.<ref name="ira-2016nov08">{{cite news |url=https://insideretail.asia/2016/11/08/jollibee-japan-opening-confirmed/ |title=Jollibee Japan opening confirmed |website=Inside Retail Asia |date=November 8, 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> within the same month JFC secured partnership with Ise Foods to open a Jollibee outlet in Japan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jollibee Japan opening confirmed|url=http://www.philretailers.com/jollibee-japan-opening-confirmed/|accessdate=2 April 2018|work=Philippine Retailers Association|date=8 November 2016}}</ref> By October 2017, the projected dates of Jollibee's entrance into the two markets were pushed to 2020.<ref name="chinaus"/>
====Others==== Jollibee has also considered reestablishing presence in Indonesia within the late 2016 to mid 2017 timeframe<ref name="expand">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/373637/economy/companies/jollibee-to-export-homegrown-brands-to-malaysia-indonesia|title=Jollibee to export homegrown brands to Malaysia, Indonesia|author=Danessa O. Rivera|publisher=GMA News|date=August 6, 2014|accessdate=August 8, 2014}}</ref> as well as to return in the [[Malaysia]] market in 2016.<ref name=thestandardnov1.2015/> Jollibee also planned to open its first branch in [[Oman]] on the same year.<ref name=thestandardnov1.2015/>
It was reported on July 2017, that Jollibee plans to reopen a branch in [[Guam]].<ref name="open1000"/><ref name="gdp-2017jul05">{{cite news |url=https://www.postguam.com/business/philippine-fast-food-jollibee-plans-guam-re-entry/article_0c914700-603b-11e7-b01b-0b50baa3e74e.html |title=Philippine fast food Jollibee plans Guam re-entry |website=Guam Daily Post |date=July 5, 2017 |first=Gaynor D. |last=Daleno}}</ref> The Marianas Business Journal report that Jollibee may return by late 2018.<ref name="mbj-2017sep18">{{cite news |url=https://mbjguam.com/2017/09/18/jollibee-to-reopen-in-guam-in-2018/ |title=Jollibee to reopen in Guam in 2018 |website=Marianas Business Journal |date=September 18, 2017 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|40em}}
[[Category:Jollibee|Locations]] [[Category:Lists of countries|Jollibee franchises]]

revision.text:
[[File:Hellenic arc.png|thumb|350px|Location of the ridge]]
The '''Mediterranean Ridge''' is a wide [[ridge]] in the bed of the [[Mediterranean Sea]], running along a rough quarter circle from [[Calabria]], south of [[Crete]], to the southwest corner of [[Turkey]], and from there eastwards south of [[Cyprus]] and Turkey.
It is an [[accretionary wedge]] caused by the [[African Plate]] [[subduction|subducting]] under the [[Eurasian Plate|Eurasian]] and [[Anatolian Plate|Anatolian]] plates. As the African Plate moves slowly north-northeastward, it is plowing up the [[Igneous rock|igneous]] and [[sedimentary rock]]s of the Mediterranean seafloor, lifting them from the seabed and creating Cyprus and other islands along the ridge.
Along the ridge, five deep basins full of [[Anoxic sea water|anoxic]] [[brine]] have been found, where [[Messinian evaporite]] deposits of brine caught up in this ongoing [[orogeny]] have dissolved.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0037073806000625|title=Exhumation of Messinian evaporites in the deep-sea and creation of deep anoxic brine-filled collapsed basins|journal=Sedimentary Geology|volume=188-189|pages=357|doi=10.1016/j.sedgeo.2006.03.013|year=2006|last1=Cita|first1=Maria Bianca |authorlink1=Maria Bianca Cita}}</ref>
In the far future, it could grow into a long high mountain range if the continued [[African Plate|northward movement of Africa]] obliterates the east part of the Mediterranean Sea.
==References== <references/>
{{Coord missing|Mediterranean}}

revision.text:
As a [[Future enlargement of the European Union#Recognised candidates|candidate country]] of the [[European Union]], '''[[Iceland]]''' (IS) is included in the '''[[Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics]] (NUTS)'''. The three NUTS levels are: * NUTS-1: IS0 Iceland * NUTS-2: IS00 Iceland * NUTS-3: Capital area / Rest of country ** IS001 Höfuðborgarsvæði ([[Capital Region (Iceland)|Capital Region]]) ** IS002 Landsbyggð (rest of country)
Below the NUTS levels, there are two [[local administrative unit|LAU]] levels (LAU-1: [[Regions of Iceland|regions]]; LAU-2: [[Municipalities of Iceland|municipalities]]).
==See also== * [[Administrative divisions of Iceland]] * [[ISO 3166-2:IS|ISO 3166-2 codes of Iceland]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (G-I)#IC: Iceland|FIPS region codes of Iceland]]
==Sources== * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/codelist_en.cfm?list=efta Hierarchical list of the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics - NUTS and the Statistical regions of Europe] * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/pngmaps/efta1.png Overview map of EFTA countries - Statistical regions at level 1] ** [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/pngmaps/is2.png ÍSLAND - Statistical regions at level 2]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ** [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/pngmaps/is3.png ÍSLAND - Statistical regions at level 3]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/statistical_regions_t1_en.html Correspondence between the regional levels and the national administrative units] * [http://www.statoids.com/uis.html Regions of Iceland], Statoids.com
{{NUTS}}

part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Madagascar-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Madagascar.svg|180|Coat of arms of Madagascar.svg|121|The [[Flag of Madagascar]]|The [[Coat of arms of Madagascar]]}} [[Image:LocationMadagascar.svg|thumb|The location of [[Madagascar]]]] [[Image:Madagascar map.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Republic of Madagascar]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Madagascar:
'''[[Madagascar]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|sovereign]] [[island nation]] located in the [[Indian Ocean]] off the southeastern coast of [[Africa]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 3, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ma.html|title=Madagascar|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> The [[Island of Madagascar]] is the [[List of islands by area|fourth-largest island in the world]], and is home to 5% of the world's [[plant]] and [[animal]] [[species]], of which more than 80% are [[Endemism|endemic]] to Madagascar. {{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} They include the [[lemur]] [[infraorder]] of [[primate]]s, the carnivorous [[Fossa (animal)|fossa]], three [[bird]] [[family (biology)|families]] and six [[Adansonia|baobab]] species.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == <!-- [[image:<General Map>|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Outline of Madagascar]]]] --> * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|m|æ|d|ə|ˈ|g|æ|s|k|ɑr}} * Common English country name: [[Madagascar]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Madagascar]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Madagascar (disambiguation)|Malagasy]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[International rankings of Madagascar]] * [[ISO country codes]]: MG, MDG, 450 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:MG]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.mg]]
== Geography of Madagascar == [[Image:Madagascar Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Madagascar]]]]
[[Geography of Madagascar]] * Madagascar is: a [[Megadiverse countries|megadiverse]] [[island country|island]] [[Nation state|country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]] and [[Southern Hemisphere]] ** [[Africa]] (off its east coast) *** [[East Africa]] *** [[Southern Africa]] ** [[Indian Ocean]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[East Africa Time]] ([[UTC+03]]) ** [[Extreme points of Madagascar]] *** High: [[Maromokotro]] {{convert|2876|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Indian Ocean]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: ''none'' ** Coastline: [[Indian Ocean]] 4,828 km * Population of Madagascar: 19,683,000 - [[List of countries by population|55th most populous country]] * Area of Madagascar: 587,041 km<sup>2</sup> * [[:commons:Atlas of Madagascar|Atlas of Madagascar]]
=== Environment of Madagascar === {{category see also|Environment of Madagascar}} [[Image:Satellite image of Madagascar in September 2003.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Madagascar]]]]
* [[Climate of Madagascar]] * [[Deforestation in Madagascar]] * [[Illegal logging in Madagascar]] * [[List of ecoregions in Madagascar|Ecoregions in Madagascar]] * [[Geology of Madagascar]] * Protected areas of Madagascar ** [[List of biosphere reserves in Madagascar|Biosphere reserves in Madagascar]] ** [[List of national parks of Madagascar|National parks of Madagascar]] * [[Wildlife of Madagascar]] ** [[Fauna of Madagascar]] *** [[List of birds of Madagascar|Birds of Madagascar]] *** [[List of mammals of Madagascar|Mammals of Madagascar]]
==== Natural geographic features of Madagascar ====
Landforms of Madagascar * Glaciers in Madagascar: none <ref>The only [[List of glaciers in Africa|glaciers in Africa]] are on Mt Kenya (in Kenya), on Kilimanjaro (in Tanzania), and in the Ruwenzori Mountains (which are located in [[Uganda]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]). See [http://iahs.info/redbooks/a126/iahs_126_0197.pdf Proceedings of the Riederalp Workshop, September 1978; Actes de l'Atelier de Riederalp, septembre 1978): IAHS-AISH Publ. no. 126, 1980.]</ref> * Mountains of Madagascar ** [[List of volcanoes in Madagascar|Volcanoes in Madagascar]] * [[List of rivers of Madagascar|Rivers of Madagascar]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Madagascar|World Heritage Sites in Madagascar]]

{{Infobox mountain | name = Pico da Neblina | photo = Pico da Neblina.jpg | photo_caption = Pico da Neblina seen from the distance, without the usual clouds. The round blue-shaded secondary peak just behind it is [[Pico 31 de Março]]. | elevation_m = 2995.30 | elevation_ref = | prominence_m = 2887 | prominence_ref=
[[List of peaks by prominence|Ranked 112th]] | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | location = State of [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]], [[Brazil]] | range = [[Cerro de la Neblina|Serra da Neblina]] ("Mountain Range of the Mists"), a section of Serra do Imeri in the [[Guiana Highlands]] | map = Brazil | map_caption = Location of Pico da Neblina in Brazil | label_position = right | coordinates = {{coord|0|48|17|N|66|00|24|W|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = [http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=8700 "Pico da Neblina, Brazil"] Peakbagger.com. Retrieved 2012-01-13. | topo = | first_ascent = 1965| easiest_route = From the town of [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]] to Iazinho river by truck, then by boat on Iazinho river, Ia river, Caburaí river and Tucano river, then on a jungle trail with three camps (Tucano, Bebedouro Novo, Garimpo do Tucano) before the final ascent. }} '''Pico da Neblina''' ({{IPA-pt|ˈpiku dɐ neˈblĩnɐ}}, ''Mist Peak'') is the highest [[mountain|peak]] in [[Brazil]], {{convert|2995.3|m|ft|0}} above sea level, in the [[Cerro de la Neblina|Serra da Neblina]], part of the [[Serra Imeri|Serra do Imeri]], a section of the [[Guiana Highlands]] on the Brazil–[[Venezuela]] border. As determined by a border survey expedition in 1962, its summit lies just within Brazilian territory, at a horizontal distance of only {{convert|687|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} from the Venezuelan border at [[Pico 31 de Março]]. As the peak's name suggests, it is shrouded in dense clouds most of the time.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was first ascended in 1965 by members of a [[Brazilian Army]] expedition. ==Location== Officially, Pico da Neblina is located in the [[municipality]] of [[Santa Isabel do Rio Negro]], state of [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]]. However, the mountain is not directly accessible from the urban seat of the municipality, which is about {{convert|180|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} away, and federal authority over the national park, the Yanomami reservation and the border security area supersedes municipal authority in all practical respects. The nearest city is actually [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]], about {{convert|140|km|mi|abbr=on}} in a straight line, from where virtually all climbing expeditions depart. The mountain is contained in the Brazilian [[Pico da Neblina National Park]]; its northern slopes are also protected in Venezuela's [[Serranía de la Neblina National Park]]. The twin parks, together with the neighbouring [[Parima Tapirapecó National Park]] (Venezuela), form a protected area complex of about 80,000 km², possibly the largest national park system in tropical rainforests in the world. Pico da Neblina is also located within the territory of the [[Yanomami]] people's reservation. ==Common misconceptions== Pico da Neblina is often mentioned as being on the exact border between [[Brazil]] and [[Venezuela]]. This is true for its [[massif]] as a whole, but the main summit is wholly in Brazil, 687 metres from the actual border.http://www.summitpost.org/neblina-peak/663648 It is also sometimes mentioned as being the highest point in [[South America]] outside of the [[Andes]], but this is not correct either: the title belongs to [[Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta]] in [[Colombia]], which is almost twice the height of Pico da Neblina and completely detached from the Andes. However, Pico da Neblina is indeed the highest point ''east'' of the Andes range, and therefore of a large portion of the continent. Neighbouring Pico 31 de Março, which ''is'' on the precise international border, is also the highest point in [[Venezuela]] outside of the Andes. ==Elevation measurements== For 39 years, based on an uncontested measurement performed in 1965 by [[Topography as the study of place|topographer]] José Ambrósio de Miranda Pombo, using a [[theodolite]], the elevation of Pico da Neblina was thought to be {{convert|3014|m|ft|0}}, but a much more accurate measurement performed in 2004 with state-of-the-art [[GPS]] equipment by [[Cartography|cartographer]] Marco Aurélio de Almeida Lima, a member of a Brazilian army expedition, put it at {{convert|2993.78|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. This was then officially recognised by the [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics]] (IBGE), the federal government's official geographic survey and census agency, which jointly organised the expedition.{{cite web|url=http://saladeimprensa.ibge.gov.br/noticias.html?view=noticia&id=1&idnoticia=267&busca=1&t=picos-bandeira-cristal-ja-tem-novas-altitudes|title=Brazilian peaks have their altitude changed|date=September 13, 2004|publisher=Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|accessdate=2016-01-13}} In February 2016, IBGE slightly revised again the official altitude of Pico da Neblina to {{convert|2995.30|m|ft}}, a 1.52-metre difference. There was no new expedition or field measurement at the time; the new value is simply a mathematical recalculation of the altitude, based on the previously obtained GPS field data, taking into account a newly available, more precise mapping of the Brazilian territory regarding the [[geoid]] (the imaginary surface based on the [[Earth]]'s [[gravitational field]] that is the reference for altitudes). This explains why Pico da Neblina and Pico 31 de Março, which are next to each other, had both exactly the same altitude correction.{{cite press release |url=https://agenciadenoticias.ibge.gov.br/agencia-noticias/2013-agencia-de-noticias/releases/15275-geociencias-ibge-reve-as-altitudes-de-sete-pontos-culminantes.html |title=Geociências: IBGE revê as altitudes de sete pontos culminantes |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Geosciences: IBGE revises the altitude of seven high points |location=Brasília |publisher=Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) |date=2016-02-29 |accessdate=2018-03-31 }} ==Geology and topography== The [[Neblina Massif]] is composed of a tilted block of sandstone overlying Precambrian [[metamorphic rock]]s. The peak is an impressive sharp rock pyramid or tooth, towering high (when the peak is visible) over the nearby lowlands on the Brazilian side, as the Imeri range quickly rises from only about 100 metres above sea level to about 2,000 metres at the base of the peak in just a few kilometres; from there the peak rises sharply. The Venezuelan side of the massif is hillier and the altitude gradient to the northern plains is less abrupt, although deep chasms and high walls still exist. Neighbouring [[Pico 31 de Março]] can be considered a secondary summit of Pico da Neblina; it has a smoother, rounder shape and is sometimes difficult to be clearly distinguished from Pico da Neblina on photographs, depending on angle and distance. Due to Pico da Neblina's equatorial latitude, while it can be cold on top, sub-freezing temperatures and frost appear to be rare (no permanent measurements are undertaken), and there is no snow. One non-authoritative source gives an average temperature of {{convert|20|C|F}} during the day and {{convert|6|C|F}} at night.{{cite web |url=http://www.suapesquisa.com/pesquisa/pico_da_neblina.htm |title=Pico da Neblina |publisher=SuaPesquisa.com |accessdate=2016-03-02 }} ==Discovery== There is little documentation available today on the peak's discovery, and virtually none of it is authoritative, even though Brazilians only discovered the mountain fairly recently, in the mid-20th century. This late discovery can be understood if one remembers how extremely remote, inaccessible and uninhabited that part of the [[Amazon region]] is even today, and that it could hardly be expected that such a high mountain (by Brazilian standards) could be found standing next to the vast, low-lying [[Amazon Basin]], even though it was known that there were mountains in that area. Moreover, as its own name states, Pico da Neblina is clouded and hidden from view most of the time. All this led to it only being discovered in the 1950s. The exact date and circumstances are obscure and not documented, but a popular story often heard in Brazil says that it was supposedly seen and reported by an airline pilot who overflew it at a luckily cloudless moment. However, the massif was known well before that on the Venezuelan side, where it was called ''Cerro Jimé''. In 1954, eight years before the Pico da Neblina was successfully climbed, the area was visited from the north by an expedition led by botanist [[Bassett Maguire]], who reached the northern summit plateau of the massif and observed the highest peak, then unnamed, estimating it to be between "8,000-9,000 feet." The whole massif was named ''Cerro de la Neblina'', since Maguire and Reynolds considered at the time that the massif constituted a separate formation from the Imeri range to the southeast. Soon after the expedition, the highest peak, although unclimbed, was named ''Pico Phelps'' in honour of eminent ornithologist [[William H. Phelps, Jr.]] At that time, the peak was thought to lie entirely within Venezuelan territory. During the 1962 Brazilian expedition, it was determined that the highest summit lies entirely in Brazil. The Brazilian expedition renamed the summit peak to ''Pico da Neblina'', causing some confusion with the name ''Cerro de la Neblina'', which is used in Venezuela to refer to the whole massif. The subsidiary summit on the Venezuelan-Brazilian border was named ''Pico 31 de Março'' in Brazil, but it is now known as ''Pico Phelps'' in Venezuela. In the 1950s, it was not yet clear whether Pico da Neblina was in Brazilian or Venezuelan territory, and its precise elevation was not yet known. Therefore, it was still widely held for many years after the peak's discovery that Brazil's highest mountain was [[Pico da Bandeira]] (2,891 m or 9,486 ft), between the southeastern states of [[Minas Gerais]] and [[Espírito Santo]], in a much more populated, developed and easily accessible region. Only in 1965 it was found and became widely known that Pico da Neblina was the country's highest mountain. Pico da Bandeira remains the highest Brazilian mountain outside of the Amazon region, and the third highest overall, after Pico da Neblina and 31 de Março. ==Access== Due to its location in a national park in a border area that is also part of [[Yanomami]] territory, access to the area is restricted and depends on a special permit by the [[Chico Mendes Institute for Biodiversity Conservation]] (ICMBio), the Brazilian government organisation responsible for national parks. The permit can be obtained at ICMBio's office in [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]], but all climbers must take an accredited local guide. A four-day trek each way should be expected, three of which consisting of a jungle trek in the rainforest that can be as hard and challenging as the climb itself. Rescue is close to impossible in the area. [[Onchocerciasis]] or "river blindness," a [[Parasitism|parasitic]] disease that can cause permanent [[blindness]] and is transmitted by a [[black fly]], is [[Endemic (epidemiology)|endemic]] in the area, albeit with a low incidence; [[malaria]] and [[yellow fever]] transmission are also possible. Therefore, climbers are advised not only to take the utmost precaution in avoiding [[insect bite]]s, but also to discuss preventive and/or therapeutic strategies with qualified physicians who are familiar with [[tropical disease]]s. Robson Czaban, a Brazilian photographer who climbed Pico da Neblina in 1998, reports on [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509161556/http://www.geocities.com/TheTropics/Cabana/5344/neblina.htm his adventure account] (in Portuguese) that there are always some gold [[Placer mining|panners]] on a small plateau just below the peak, at about 2,000 m (6,100 ft), called Garimpo do Tucano, which serves as the base camp for the last and steepest part of the climb. While the panners' presence there is technically illegal, they are widely tolerated by Brazilian authorities, and Czaban speculates that this would be because in such a remote area, they are believed to watch the border and nature better than the park rangers and the army would have the means to do. Czaban reports them to be very friendly and helpful. ==See also== * [[Pico 31 de Março]] * [[Pico da Neblina National Park]] * [[Guiana Highlands]] ==References== {{more footnotes|article|date=January 2010}} {{reflist}} * Maguire, Bassett and Reynolds, Charles D. (1955) "Cerro de la Neblina, Amazonas, Venezuela: A Newly discovered Sandstone Mountain" ''Geographical Review'' 45(1): pp. 27–51 * Instituto Brasileiro de Desenvolvimento Florestal (1979) ''Plano do Sistema de Unidades de Conservação do Brasil''. Ministério da Agricultura (MA), Instituto Brasileiro de Desenvolvimento Florestal (IBDF) and Fundação Brasileira para a Conservação da Natureza (FBCN), Brasília, D.F., [http://worldcat.org/oclc/6944034 OCLC 6944034]. In Portuguese, covers the geology, geomorphology, climate, soils, vegetation and fauna of Pico da Neblina National Park. * Gentry, A.H. (1986) "Exploring the Mountain of the Mists" ''Science Year: The World Book Science Annual'' pp. 124–139 it is a big mountain ==External links== * [http://picasaweb.google.com.br/orleisrjunior/ExpedicaoNeblina# Picasa gallery of photographs]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from two Brazilian private expeditions to Pico da Neblina, maintained by the Brazilian [http://www.mundovertical.com/ Mundo Vertical] mountaineering site * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509161556/http://www.geocities.com/TheTropics/Cabana/5344/neblina.htm Robson Czaban's 1998 climb] of Pico da Neblina - very detailed report (in Portuguese) of his visit to the peak, which originated some the pictures linked above, with its own [https://web.archive.org/web/20000623183458/http://www.geocities.com/TheTropics/Cabana/5344/neblina_album.htm picture album] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111006064614/http://aventure-se.ig.com.br/materias/17/0001-0100/53/53_01.html João Paulo Barbosa's 1999 expedition] - another very detailed account (in Portuguese) {{Brazilian states highest points}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Neblina}} [[Category:Mountains of Brazil]] [[Category:Mountains of Venezuela]] [[Category:Highest points of Brazilian states]] [[Category:Landforms of Amazonas (Brazilian state)]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] [[Category:Extreme points of Brazil]]

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2009}} The '''Pratomagno''' is a mountain range which has the [[Arno River]] on both sides: to the west is the upper [[Valdarno]] and to the east is the [[Casentino]]. It lies north-west of the city of [[Arezzo]], in [[Tuscany]], [[Italy]].
Its highest peak has an elevation of 1,592 m.

[[File:SlaperdijkHondsbossche.jpg|thumb|A typical sleeper dike near the [[Hondsbossche Zeewering]]. In 1570, this dike prevented the flooding of [[North Holland]] during the [[All Saints' Flood (1570)]] after the breakthrough of the Hondsbossche Zeewering.]] A '''sleeper dike''' (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] ''slaperdijk'') is a [[Dike (construction)|dike]] which does not normally face water, but serves as a backup if a "front-line" dike in front of it breaks.
The sleeper dikes are usually located at places where there is a high risk of dike breakthrough or where there used to be such a risk. The dike is only potentially safeguarding the land from the sea/river, and is "sleeping", hence the name. Sometimes there is even a secondary sleeper dike, which can be called a "[[dreamer dike]]".
Many of the sleeper dikes are historical, and no longer have a function in protection against the water, after the dike improvements of the [[Delta Plan]] . However, in case of a breakthrough they do divide up the land in sections, and therefore stop the waterflow in some parts, and slow down in others. Also many of these dikes are protected because of their cultural historical and ecological value.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sleeper Dike}} [[Category:Disaster preparedness]] [[Category:Geography of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dikes]]

'''James Anthony (Tony) Binns''' (born 1948 in Greater Manchester)<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.otago.ac.nz/otagomagazine/otago004397.pdf|journal=University of Otago Magazine|issue=12|date=October 2005|title=The World at his Feet|first=Simon|last=Cunliffe|page=25}}</ref> is the Ron Lister Professor of Geography at the [[University of Otago]] in New Zealand.
==Background== Tony Binns was born in [[Prestwich]] and grew up in Bury, Greater Manchester, UK. He attended Stand Grammar School,<ref>Demolished 2001. http://www.prestwichandwhitefieldguide.co.uk/news/prestwich_history/8259040.Stand_Grammar___s_rescue/</ref> [[Whitefield, Greater Manchester|Whitefield]]. He graduated from [[Sheffield University]] (Geography, 1970; Dip.Ed., 1971) and taught geography in schools while attending the [[University of Birmingham]] (MA African Studies 1973; PhD African Studies and Geography, 1981). He taught geography at [[University of Sussex]] from 1975-2004, before moving to the [[University of Otago]] as Professor and latterly Head of Department.
Binns has two children, and holds British and New Zealand citizenship.
==Scholarly Contributions==
Binns' prime interest is African community development and the livelihoods and wellbeing of Africans. His early work was in [[Sierra Leone]], working from [[Kaima|Kayima]] in the north east of the country on links between diamond mining and the farming sector, the two main occupations of local residents. He has continued to follow these trends since 1974, and in 2014 he was elected an honorary chief of Kayima for his continued support to the community.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Exauhkk9Kyc</ref>
Since then he has worked in *South Africa (local economic development initiatives, community-based institutions and empowerment in South Africa, exporting ‘alternative’ foods and [[fair trade]], livelihoods of the West Coast region including wildflower harvesting, and the ‘Working for Water’ programme) *Sierra Leone (agricultural development and change in the Eastern Province; reconstruction and development in the post-conflict period; integrated rural development; urban and peri-urban farming in Freetown) *Nigeria (urban and peri-urban agricultural production in [[Kano]], pressures facing pastoral livelihoods in northern Nigeria, pastoral-farmer conflict, and degradation in the Kano close-settled zone) *Morocco (small-scale irrigation development in the High Atlas mountains) *The Gambia (export-orientated horticultural production) *Zambia (urban and peri-urban agricultural production in Lusaka, urban agriculture in the Zambian Copper Belt) *Kenya (relationships between farming and fishing in the Kenyan sector of Lake Victoria).
He has also worked in *Samoa (the role of the church in development) *Vietnam (urban and peri-urban agricultural production in Hanoi) *and New Zealand.<ref>http://www.geography.otago.ac.nz/people/academic/tony_binns</ref>
==Recognition== *President of the Geographical Association 1994-1995 *Leverhulme Study Abroad Fellowship 2000-2001 (at [[Rhodes University]]), South Africa *Director and Council member of Worldaware (UK-based development education organisation) 1995-2004 *President of the [http://www.commonwealthgeography.org Commonwealth Geographical Bureau] (2009-2016). *President of the New Zealand Geographical Society (2010-2011). *Distinguished New Zealand Geographer Medal 2012. *Chief Manjawah of Sandor (master farmer), and Sahr Kayima (first son of Kayima), Sierra Leone, 2014
